elements.content: Complexes of lanthanides­(III) (Ce–Yb) with 2,2′-bis­(2-oxazoline) (Box) combined with octacyanidomolybdate­(V) gave a series of magneto-luminescent coordination polymers, {[LnIII(Box) n (DMF) m ]­[MoV(CN)8]}·x(solvent) (1–12). They are built of cyanido-bridged layers of a mixed 4- and 8-metal rings topology and show unique sliding of layers dependent on a 4f metal ion. For light lanthanides, dominant phase A, {[LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2]­[MoV(CN)8]}·1.5MeCN (Ln = Ce, 1; Pr, 2; Nd, 3), consists of ideally aligned, not shifted layers, giving large channels (13.7 × 14.0 Å). Intermediate lanthanides reveal phase B, {[LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2] [MoV(CN)8]}·H2O (Ln = Sm, 4; Eu, 5; Gd, 6; Tb, 7; Dy, 8), of smaller pores (8.4 × 10.6 Å) due to layer-H2O hydrogen bonding, which induces sliding of CN–-bridged layers. Heavy lanthanides show phase C, {[LnIII(Box)­(DMF)3]­[MoV(CN)8]}·MeCN (Ln = Ho, 9; Er, 10; Tm, 11; Yb, 12), with large channels (13.7 × 13.7 Å) of a similar size to light lanthanides. This effect comes from the changes in LnIII coordination sphere affecting solvent–layer interactions. Compounds 1–12 reveal diverse emission depending on the interaction between LnIII and Box luminophors. For 2–5, 9, and 12, the ligand-to-metal energy-transfer-induced visible f-centered emission ranging from green for HoIII-based 9, orange from SmIII-based 4, to red for PrIII- and EuIII-containing 2 and 5, respectively. Near-infrared emission was found for 2–4, 9, and 12. Red phosphorescence of Box was detected for GdIII-based 6, whereas the selective excitation of ligand or LnIII excited states resulting in the switchable red to green emission was found for TbIII-based 7. The materials revealed LnIII–MoV magnetic coupling leading to ferromagnetism below 2.0 and 2.2 K for 4 and 7, respectively. The onset of magnetic ordering at low temperatures was found for 6 and 8. Compounds 1–12 form a unique family of cyanido-bridged materials of a bifunctional magneto-luminescence character combined with dynamic structural features.

elements.content: A series of two-dimensional cyanido-bridged {[LnIII(Box)n(DMF)m]­[MoV(CN)8]}·x(solvent) (Ln = Ce−Yb; Box = 2,2′-bis­(2-oxazoline)) coordination polymers have been synthesized and characterized. They reveal unique two-step Ln-dependent sliding of coordination layers modulating the size of channels within their microporous structure. They form an interesting family of bifunctional magneto-luminescent materials combining magnetic coupling leading to magnetic ordering with the visible to near-infrared emission realized by ligand-to-metal energy transfer or selective excitation of ligand or metal excited states.

They form an interesting family of bifunctional magneto-luminescent materials combining magnetic coupling leading to magnetic ordering with the visible to near-infrared emission realized by ligand-to-metal energy transfer or selective excitation of ligand or metal excited states.

elements.content: Multifunctional materials, combining at least two magnetic, electrical, or optical properties, are of a special interest as they serve as promising prerequisites for the application in information storage, selective sensing, and construction of fast, economical electronic devices. In this regard, the great effort is focused on the synthesis of molecular magnets which are built of magnetically active complexes of metal ions, or organic radicals. They differ from the metal- or metal-oxides-based magnets as their structure, and resulting properties, can be designed by the choice of building blocks, selected from an unlimited set of organic/inorganic molecules. Molecular magnets can reveal not only exchange interaction leading to magnetic ordering below critical temperature (T c) but also unique effect of slow magnetic relaxation giving the magnetic hysteresis of a single molecule origin. Moreover, these properties can be combined with other functionalities, such as ferroelectricity, sensitivity to guest molecules, chirality, or luminescence.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Multifunctional materials, combining at least two magnetic, electrical, or optical properties, are of a special interest as they serve as promising prerequisites for the application in information storage, selective sensing, and construction of fast, economical electronic devices. In this regard, the great effort is focused on the synthesis of molecular magnets which are built of magnetically active complexes of metal ions, or organic radicals. They differ from the metal- or metal-oxides-based magnets as their structure, and resulting properties, can be designed by the choice of building blocks, selected from an unlimited set of organic/inorganic molecules. Molecular magnets can reveal not only exchange interaction leading to magnetic ordering below critical temperature (T c) but also unique effect of slow magnetic relaxation giving the magnetic hysteresis of a single molecule origin. Moreover, these properties can be combined with other functionalities, such as ferroelectricity, sensitivity to guest molecules, chirality, or luminescence.

elements.content: The properties implemented into a multifunctional material can coexist, modify each other, or interact giving a cross-effect. The spectacular phenomena are induced when the introduced property is combined with magnetic ordering. It opened remarkable families of conductive magnets, molecular multiferroics, and magnetic sponges with T c triggered by dehydration. Among others, the conjunction of magnetism with optical properties was shown to be fruitful. Chirality combined with magnetic ordering lead to a cross-effect of magneto-chiral dichroism enhanced below T c as shown for oxalate-bridged MnII–CrIII (T c = 7 K) ferromagnet with chiral counterion. Enantiopure magnets reveal natural (NCD) and magnetic circular dichroism (MCD), with the enhancement of MCD below T c, as proved for CN–-bridged MnII(L)–NbIV (T c = 23.5 K, L = α-methyl-2-pyridine methanol) ferrimagnet. Second harmonic generation (SHG) is also modulated when combined with magnetic ordering. The related effect of magnetization-induced SHG was presented in both selected oxalate- and cyanido-bridged molecular magnets. Particular attention is paid to photomagnetic materials which can switch between two or more magnetic states by light irradiation, and even the switchability between the nonmagnetized and magnetically ordered state can be found. Such a light-induced magnet is realized by the induction of charge transfer in bimetallic assemblies built of 3d metal ions and cyanidometallates. The alternative way is based on light-induced spin-crossover as shown for octacyanido-based FeII(L)–NbIV (L = 4-pyridinealdoxime) photomagnet. Using this approach, we prepared a first chiral FeII(L)–NbIV (L = 4-bromopyridine) photomagnet, and a cross-effect of 90° optical switching of output SHG was detected.

elements.content: A great potential lies also in emissive molecular magnets combining magnetic ordering with luminescence, which are an alternative to luminescent magnetic nanocomposites built of fluorescent quantum dots bounded with magnetic nanoparticles. In contrast to these materials, for which emission and magnetism originate from two independent ingredients, emissive molecular magnets are intrinsically both emissive and magnetic. It gives the opportunity to detect a diversity of luminescent effects in a magnetic system and the coupling between both properties. However, magnetic ordering with emission were found only for a small group of molecular materials, consisting of a carboxylate-bridged NiII network (T c = 9.5 K, ligand emission), cyanido-bridged TbIII–WV ferromagnets (T c = 2.8 K, TbIII emission; T c = 2.4 K, TbIII and ligand emission), as well as oxamato-bridged CoII–CuII (T c = 19 K, emission of RuII-based counterion), and MnII–CuII (T c = 19 K, luminescent organic counterion) magnets.

elements.content: All these examples show an increasing interest in functional molecular magnets, especially of a magneto-optical character. However, the main effort is focused on searching for single novel materials with exceptional functionalities. Although this approach ensures scientific progress, the absence of reports on systematic work disallows the understanding of multifuctionalities and a selection of the best building blocks for the enhancement of desired properties. We thus have undertaken the challenge of systematic studies of magneto-optical functionalities in molecular magnets, starting from the luminescence combined with magnetic properties. We selected coordination assemblies based on lanthanides­(III) and paramagnetic octacyanidometallates, offering eight cyanides for mediating in magnetic interactions, which often leads to magnetic ordering. They are not emissive but do not absorb the visible and near-infrared light, thereby allowing the observation of luminescence from other building blocks. Most of the lanthanide­(III) ions are paramagnetic, and they often reveal magnetic anisotropy, inducing unusual magnetic properties alone and in combination with [M­(CN)8] n− ions. Most lanthanides­(III) are emissive in either the visible or near-infrared range, and they show a variety of luminescent effects, including strong interaction with ligands serving as an antenna for enhanced f-centered emission. The family of paramagnetic lanthanides­(III) consists of 12 members, and their reactivity is very similar, so a broad series can be investigated in details. However, due to the increasing ionic radius, their reactivity can change, going from light to heavy lanthanides, which affects the structural features and properties. This effect was found in a series of LnIII(2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine)–WV systems changing from chains for Ce–Dy, to dinuclear molecules for Ho–Yb.

elements.content: At the current time, only a few magneto-luminescent materials based on a 4f metal and [M­(CN)8]3– (M = Mo, W) have been reported. The visible TbIII and EuIII emission was found for {[MIII(H2O)5]­[MV(CN)8]} (MIII = Eu, Tb; Eu–Gd, Eu–Tb, Tb–Sm = 1:1; M = Mo, W) 2-D magnets, whereas NIR luminescence was presented in NdIII(1,10-phenanthroline)–Mo/WV chains bearing ferromagnetic coupling. We have shown a pair of enantiopure EuIII(iPr-Pybox)–WV (iPr-Pybox = 2,6-bis­(4-isopropyl-2-oxazolin-2-yl)­pyridine) helical chains revealing chirality, paramagnetism, and thermally switchable luminescence. Later, the chiral helices of NdIII–WV and GdIII–WV have been characterized, and they showed ferromagnetic coupling with NdIII-based near-infrared emission and antiferromagnetic coupling with red ligand phosphorescence, respectively. The interesting magnetic properties, including magnetic ordering, have been also found for other LnIII–[M­(CN)8] systems, but their emission has not been examined.

The visible TbIII and EuIII emission was found for {[MIII(H2O)5][MV(CN)8]} (MIII = Eu, Tb; Eu-Gd, Eu-Tb, Tb-Sm = 1:1; M = Mo, W) 2-D magnets, whereas NIR luminescence was presented in NdIII(1,10-phenanthroline)-Mo/WV chains bearing ferromagnetic coupling. We have shown a pair of enantiopure EuIII(iPr-Pybox)-WV (iPr-Pybox = 2,6-bis(4-isopropyl-2-oxazolin-2-yl)pyridine) helical chains revealing chirality, paramagnetism, and thermally switchable luminescence. Later, the chiral helices of NdIII-WV and GdIII-WV have been characterized, and they showed ferromagnetic coupling with NdIII-based near-infrared emission and antiferromagnetic coupling with red ligand phosphorescence, respectively. The interesting magnetic properties, including magnetic ordering, have been also found for other LnIII-[M(CN)8] systems, but their emission has not been examined.

elements.content: More importantly, we have recently reported a cyanido-bridged TbIII(L)–WV (T c = 2.4 K, L = 2,2′-bis­(2-oxazoline)) layered ferromagnet showing a switchability between TbIII-centered green and ligand-based red emission by using a different wavelength of excitation light. It showed that combination of LnIII with Box ligand and [MV(CN)8]3– resulted in magnetic interactions and ordering, coexisting with various emission properties coming from the interaction between f-metal and ligand excited states. Here, we follow these discoveries, and report the synthesis and detailed structural, optical and magnetic studies of a series of {[LnIII(Box) n (DMF) m ]­[MoV(CN)8]}·x(solvent) (Ln = Ce–Yb, 1–12) layered materials combining Ln-dependent diversity of luminescent and magnetic phenomena, as well as unusual two-step sliding of cyanido-bridged layers.

It showed that combination of LnIII with Box ligand and [MV(CN)8]3- resulted in magnetic interactions and ordering, coexisting with various emission properties coming from the interaction between f-metal and ligand excited states. Here, we follow these discoveries, and report the synthesis and detailed structural, optical and magnetic studies of a series of {[LnIII(Box) n (DMF) m ][MoV(CN)8]}⋅x(solvent) (Ln = Ce-Yb, 1-12) layered materials combining Ln-dependent diversity of luminescent and magnetic phenomena, as well as unusual two-step sliding of cyanido-bridged layers.

elements.content: The tetrabutyl­ammonium octacyanido­molybdate­(V), TBA3[MoV(CN)8] was synthesized according to the published procedure. 2,2′-Bis­(2-oxazoline) (Box), lanthanides­(III) nitrates n-hydrates, and all solvents (acetonitrile = MeCN, N,N-dimethylformamide = DMF, diethyl ether = Et2O) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry or Wako Chemicals GmbH.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The tetrabutylammonium octacyanidomolybdate(V), TBA3[MoV(CN)8] was synthesized according to the published procedure. 2,2'-Bis(2-oxazoline) (Box), lanthanides(III) nitrates n-hydrates, and all solvents (acetonitrile = MeCN, N,N-dimethylformamide = DMF, diethyl ether = Et2O) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry or Wako Chemicals GmbH.

elements.content: To ensure a reliable comparison of reactivity, the same synthetic procedures were used for 1–12. The n-hydrated lanthanide­(III) nitrate (n = 4–6, 0.02 mmol) and 2,2′-bis­(2-oxazoline) (8.4 mg, 0.06 mmol) were dissolved in 2.0 mL of MeCN, and the resulting solution was stirred for 5 min. Then, the portion of DMF (100 μL, 1.2 mmol) was added, and further stirring for 5 min was performed. After that, the solution of TBA3[MoV(CN)8] (20.6 mg, 0.02 mmol) in 1.0 mL of MeCN was added. The resulting yellow solution was briefly stirred and layered by Et2O (∼5.0 mL). After a few days, a reasonable amount of crystals appeared. The shape, color, and stability of the crystals upon exposure to the air depend on the lanthanide ion. For IR spectra and CHN analysis, the crystals were filtrated, washed by Et2O, and dried in air. For the single-crystal X-ray experiment and other measurements, the crystals were protected from the contact with air in various ways, depending on the physical technique (see below).
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses and Basic Characterization of 1-12 

To ensure a reliable comparison of reactivity, the same synthetic procedures were used for 1-12. The n-hydrated lanthanide(III) nitrate (n = 4-6, 0.02 mmol) and 2,2'-bis(2-oxazoline) (8.4 mg, 0.06 mmol) were dissolved in 2.0 mL of MeCN, and the resulting solution was stirred for 5 min. Then, the portion of DMF (100 μL, 1.2 mmol) was added, and further stirring for 5 min was performed. After that, the solution of TBA3[MoV(CN)8] (20.6 mg, 0.02 mmol) in 1.0 mL of MeCN was added. The resulting yellow solution was briefly stirred and layered by Et2O (~5.0 mL). After a few days, a reasonable amount of crystals appeared. The shape, color, and stability of the crystals upon exposure to the air depend on the lanthanide ion. For IR spectra and CHN analysis, the crystals were filtrated, washed by Et2O, and dried in air. For the single-crystal X-ray experiment and other measurements, the crystals were protected from the contact with air in various ways, depending on the physical technique (see below).

elements.content: The title compound was produced as yellowish green needle crystals. The formula was found from the X-ray diffraction experiment. After filtration, washing by Et2O, and air-drying, 1 exchanges MeCN solvent into H2O to give air-stable composition, [CeIII(Box)2(DMF)2]2[MoV(CN)8]2·3H2O (formula taken from CHN analysis). Yield: 6.2 mg, 34%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2178w, 2172w, 2163m, 2152m, 2130w. Anal. Calcd for Ce1Mo1C26H36N14O9 (M w = 924.7 g·mol–1): C, 33.77%; H, 3.92%; N, 21.21%. Found: C, 33.64%; H, 4.01%; N, 21.10%. It is important to note that among the overwhelming amount of needle crystals, a few block crystals were observed. They are the second phase, [CeIII(Box)2(DMF)2]2[MoV(CN)8]2·H2O, analogous to that found for 2–8. However, the quality of these crystals were poor, and attempts to characterize them by X-ray experiment were unsuccessful.

elements.content: The title compound was produced as yellow block crystals. The formula was found from the results of X-ray diffraction experiment. This phase grows as a small impurity among the large amount of needle crystals of 2a. Only the X-ray diffraction experiment was performed for 2b. For other physical measurements, the properties of 2a are presented. It was verified, however, that the physical properties of 2 are not noticeably affected by the variable amount of 2b.

For other physical measurements, the properties of 3a are shown. It was additionally confirmed that the physical properties of 3 are not noticeably affected by the variable amount of 3b.

elements.content: Single-crystal diffraction data of 1, 2ab, 3ab, and 4–12 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The single crystals were dispersed in Apiezon N grease for air-unstable 1, 2a, 3a, 9–12, or Paratone N oil for air-stable 2b, 3b, 4–8 (Figure S1, ). The measurements for 1–8 were conducted at 90(2) K and for 9–12 at 210(2) or 250(2) K. The crystal structures were solved by a direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-97. Calculations were performed using Crystal Structure software and the WinGX (ver. 1.80.05) integrated system. Except for a few disordered solvent molecules in 1–3a, all non-hydrogen atoms in 1–12 were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of 3b, 4, 5, and 7 have been found independently and refined isotropically, whereas the H atoms positions in 1, 3a, 9–12 have been calculated with an idealized geometry and refined using a riding model. In the cases of 2ab, 6, and 8, the mixed treating of H atoms was applied. Due to the structural disorder, found especially in 1, 2a, 3a, and 9–12, some restraints on C–C and C–N distances in solvent MeCN molecules and weak restraints on thermal ellipsoids of some terminal cyanides, DMF, and solvents have been used in order to maintain the proper geometry. The crystal structures were deposited in CCDC, and the related references numbers are 1039131–1039144 for 1, 2ab, 3ab, 4–12, respectively.

Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal diffraction data of 1, 2ab, 3ab, and 4-12 were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The single crystals were dispersed in Apiezon N grease for air-unstable 1, 2a, 3a, 9-12, or Paratone N oil for air-stable 2b, 3b, 4-8 (Figure S1, ). The measurements for 1-8 were conducted at 90(2) K and for 9-12 at 210(2) or 250(2) K. The crystal structures were solved by a direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-97. Calculations were performed using Crystal Structure software and the WinGX (ver. 1.80.05) integrated system. Except for a few disordered solvent molecules in 1-3a, all non-hydrogen atoms in 1-12 were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of 3b, 4, 5, and 7 have been found independently and refined isotropically, whereas the H atoms positions in 1, 3a, 9-12 have been calculated with an idealized geometry and refined using a riding model. In the cases of 2ab, 6, and 8, the mixed treating of H atoms was applied. Due to the structural disorder, found especially in 1, 2a, 3a, and 9-12, some restraints on C-C and C-N distances in solvent MeCN molecules and weak restraints on thermal ellipsoids of some terminal cyanides, DMF, and solvents have been used in order to maintain the proper geometry. The crystal structures were deposited in CCDC, and the related references numbers are 1039131-1039144 for 1, 2ab, 3ab, 4-12, respectively.

elements.content: IR spectra were recorded on JASCO FTIR-4100 spectrometer in the 4000–400 cm–1 range on dried samples mixed with KBr. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were measured by a Shimadzu UV-3100 spectrometer for dried samples mixed with BaSO4. UV–vis-NIR emission and excitation spectra were collected using a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 (FL3-211) spectrofluorimeter (model TKN-7) equipped with a Xe (450 W) lamp as excitation source. For the UV–vis range, a room-temperature R928P emission detector operating in photon-counting mode was applied. For the NIR region, a liquid-nitrogen-cooled version of an InGaAs photodiode detector DSS-IGA020L was used. The emission and excitation data were analyzed using FluorEssence software. To prevent the removal of solvent, all experiments were performed on the crystalline samples covered by a pure solvent. All spectra were collected at 77 K in a cryostat filled with liquid N2. During long excitation, the emission gradually decreased, probably due to UV-induced photoreactivity involving the photoreduction of [MoV(CN)8]3– moieties and subsequent partial decomposition. This difficulty has been previously observed in other emissive systems built of lanthanides­(III) and octacyanidometallates­(V). Magnetic properties were investigated using a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer (Quantum Design). It was confirmed that the magnetic properties of the crystals left in the mother solution and those of the freshly dried samples were identical. Therefore, the results of measurements for only the freshly dried powder samples are presented. The magnetic susceptibility data were corrected for the diamagnetic contributions using Pascal constants.

For the UV-vis range, a room-temperature R928P emission detector operating in photon-counting mode was applied. For the NIR region, a liquid-nitrogen-cooled version of an InGaAs photodiode detector DSS-IGA020L was used. The emission and excitation data were analyzed using FluorEssence software. To prevent the removal of solvent, all experiments were performed on the crystalline samples covered by a pure solvent. All spectra were collected at 77 K in a cryostat filled with liquid N2. During long excitation, the emission gradually decreased, probably due to UV-induced photoreactivity involving the photoreduction of [MoV(CN)8]3- moieties and subsequent partial decomposition. This difficulty has been previously observed in other emissive systems built of lanthanides(III) and octacyanidometallates(V). Magnetic properties were investigated using a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer (Quantum Design). It was confirmed that the magnetic properties of the crystals left in the mother solution and those of the freshly dried samples were identical. Therefore, the results of measurements for only the freshly dried powder samples are presented. The magnetic susceptibility data were corrected for the diamagnetic contributions using Pascal constants.

elements.content:
Continuous Shape Measure Analyses for coordination spheres of [MoV(CN)8]3–, and LnIII (Ln = Ce–Yb) complexes were performed using SHAPE software ver. 2.1.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structures

The high-quality single-crystals of 1–12 were prepared by layering of Et2O onto MeCN solutions of LnIII(NO3)3·nH2O (Ln = Ce–Yb), Box (bis-oxazoline), and TBA3[MoV(CN)8] containing a small addition of DMF. Depending on lanthanide­(III), three crystalline phases were observed: (i) needles for light lanthanides (Ce, 1; Pr, 2a; Nd, 3a), denoted as phase A, (ii) flattened blocks for middle lanthanides (Sm, 4; Eu. 5; Gd, 6; Tb, 7; Dy, 8) of phase B, found also as a minor phase for Pr (2b) and Nd (3b), and (iii) larger blocks for heavy lanthanides (Ho, 9; Er, 10; Tm, 11; Yb, 12), called phase C (Figure S1, ). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments indicate that phase A is triclinic with P-1 space group when phase B and C are monoclinic of P 21/n space group but differing in the unit cell parameters (). Despite these differences, all compounds, 1–12 are cyanido-bridged layers of a mixed 4- and 8-membered metal rings topology (Figure , ). The layers comprise octametallic Ln4Mo4(CN) 8 units, built of four [MoV(CN)8]3– ions alternately connected with four LnIII complexes with Box and DMF. The same building blocks create also tetrametallic Ln2Mo2(CN)4 squares which link four different Ln4Mo4(CN)8 moieties resulting in 2-D coordination skeleton (Figure ).

Calculations

Continuous Shape Measure Analyses for coordination spheres of [MoV(CN)8]3-, and LnIII (Ln = Ce-Yb) complexes were performed using SHAPE software ver. 2.1. 

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

The high-quality single-crystals of 1-12 were prepared by layering of Et2O onto MeCN solutions of LnIII(NO3)3⋅nH2O (Ln = Ce-Yb), Box (bis-oxazoline), and TBA3[MoV(CN)8] containing a small addition of DMF. Depending on lanthanide(III), three crystalline phases were observed: (i) needles for light lanthanides (Ce, 1; Pr, 2a; Nd, 3a), denoted as phase A, (ii) flattened blocks for middle lanthanides (Sm, 4; Eu. 5; Gd, 6; Tb, 7; Dy, 8) of phase B, found also as a minor phase for Pr (2b) and Nd (3b), and (iii) larger blocks for heavy lanthanides (Ho, 9; Er, 10; Tm, 11; Yb, 12), called phase C (Figure S1, ). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments indicate that phase A is triclinic with P-1 space group when phase B and C are monoclinic of P 21/n space group but differing in the unit cell parameters (). Despite these differences, all compounds, 1-12 are cyanido-bridged layers of a mixed 4- and 8-membered metal rings topology (Figure , ). The layers comprise octametallic Ln4Mo4(CN) 8 units, built of four [MoV(CN)8]3- ions alternately connected with four LnIII complexes with Box and DMF. The same building blocks create also tetrametallic Ln2Mo2(CN)4 squares which link four different Ln4Mo4(CN)8 moieties resulting in 2-D coordination skeleton (Figure ).

elements.content: Crystal structures of 1–12: triclinic type A phases of 1, 2a, and 3a, monoclinic type B phases of 2b, 3b, 4–8, and monoclinic type C phases of 9–12. Structural views present: (a) the single coordination layer in the perpendicular view, (b) the building unit of coordination layer, and (c, d) the spatial arrangement of layers and solvent molecules between them (acetonitrile–green, water–blue).

Structural views present: (a) the single coordination layer in the perpendicular view, (b) the building unit of coordination layer, and (c, d) the spatial arrangement of layers and solvent molecules between them (acetonitrile-green, water-blue).

elements.content: Although the overall topology was found to be identical, the details of LnIII coordination sphere and alignment of layers are different for phases A (1–3), B (2b, 3b, 4–8), and C (9–12). The asymmetric unit of phase A contains two [MoV(CN)8]3–, two [LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2]3+ ions (Ln = Ce–Nd), and a few disordered MeCN molecules (Figures and ). Each of the [MoV(CN)8]3– ions form three cyanide bridges, whereas the five remaining cyanides are terminal. Interestingly, Mo1 reveals the geometry of a dodecahedron (DD-8, D 2d symmetry), and Mo2 is described as a square antiprism (SAPR-8, D 4d,). LnIII coordinates three nitrogen of cyanides, two O atoms of DMF, and four N atoms of two Box ligands, giving a nine-coordinated complex of a capped square antiprism geometry (CSAPR-9, C 4v, ). Despite the same coordination spheres, Ln1 and Ln2 differ in the spatial arrangement of ligands. In Ln1, Box ligands are aligned almost parallel with the Box–Box torsion angle close to 160°, when for Ln2, Box rings are perpendicular to each other with the torsion angle ∼90°. Consequently, the O­(DMF)–Ln-O­(DMF) angle is around 80° for Ln1, while an obtuse angle close to 150° is observed for Ln2.
elements.clean_text: Although the overall topology was found to be identical, the details of LnIII coordination sphere and alignment of layers are different for phases A (1-3), B (2b, 3b, 4-8), and C (9-12). The asymmetric unit of phase A contains two [MoV(CN)8]3-, two [LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2]3+ ions (Ln = Ce-Nd), and a few disordered MeCN molecules (Figures  and ). Each of the [MoV(CN)8]3- ions form three cyanide bridges, whereas the five remaining cyanides are terminal. Interestingly, Mo1 reveals the geometry of a dodecahedron (DD-8, D 2d symmetry), and Mo2 is described as a square antiprism (SAPR-8, D 4d,). LnIII coordinates three nitrogen of cyanides, two O atoms of DMF, and four N atoms of two Box ligands, giving a nine-coordinated complex of a capped square antiprism geometry (CSAPR-9, C 4v, ). Despite the same coordination spheres, Ln1 and Ln2 differ in the spatial arrangement of ligands. In Ln1, Box ligands are aligned almost parallel with the Box-Box torsion angle close to 160°, when for Ln2, Box rings are perpendicular to each other with the torsion angle ~90°. Consequently, the O(DMF)-Ln-O(DMF) angle is around 80° for Ln1, while an obtuse angle close to 150° is observed for Ln2.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of phase B is constructed of one [MoV(CN)8]3– and one [LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2]3+ ion accompanied by one H2O molecule (Figures and ). Similarly to phase A, the [MoV(CN)8]3– moiety forms three cyanide bridges and reveals a DD-8 geometry (). The coordination sphere and a CSAPR-9 geometry of Ln1 in phase B is the same as for phase A (). However, exclusively, one type of spatial arrangement of ligands, with almost perpendicular alignment of Box molecules and Box–Box torsion angle of ∼90°, is observed. In the asymmetric unit of phase C, also only one [MoV(CN)8]3– and one LnIII complex is present, but they are accompanied by one uncoordinated MeCN molecule instead of H2O, as found in phase B (Figures and ). The [MoV(CN)8]3– ion forms three cyanide bridges, but the geometry is close to an ideal SAPR-8 (). LnIII coordinates three N atoms of cyanides, two N atoms of only one Box, and three O atoms of DMF molecules. This gives an eight-coordinated complex of a DD-8 geometry, different to those observed for phases A and B (). The Ln-dependent variation of crucial structural parameters on going from phase A to B to C was summarized in Figure (see also ).

The coordination sphere and a CSAPR-9 geometry of Ln1 in phase B is the same as for phase A (). However, exclusively, one type of spatial arrangement of ligands, with almost perpendicular alignment of Box molecules and Box-Box torsion angle of ~90°, is observed. In the asymmetric unit of phase C, also only one [MoV(CN)8]3- and one LnIII complex is present, but they are accompanied by one uncoordinated MeCN molecule instead of H2O, as found in phase B (Figures  and ). The [MoV(CN)8]3- ion forms three cyanide bridges, but the geometry is close to an ideal SAPR-8 (). LnIII coordinates three N atoms of cyanides, two N atoms of only one Box, and three O atoms of DMF molecules. This gives an eight-coordinated complex of a DD-8 geometry, different to those observed for phases A and B (). The Ln-dependent variation of crucial structural parameters on going from phase A to B to C was summarized in Figure  (see also ).

elements.content: The changes in coordination spheres of LnIII in phases A, B, and C affect the size of Ln4Mo4(CN)8 and Ln2Mo2(CN)4 rings of cyanido-bridged layers. Phase A shows flattened layers with larger rings of 13.7 × 14.0 Å and smaller rings with 5.8 × 5.8 Å size, while multimetallic rings of bent layers in phase B are of the 12.5 × 14.7 Å and 5.8 × 5.8 Å sizes. Phase C reveals almost flat layers with rings of the 13.7 × 13.7 Å and 5.6 × 5.7 Å sizes. The neighboring layers for phases A and C are aligned ideally one above another, so as the large Ln4Mo4 rings of one layer are located above the large rings on the next layer, giving the microporous structure built of broad channels with dimensions corresponding to the size of octametallic rings. On the contrary, layers of phase B are arranged with the shift between neighboring layers as the smaller Ln2Mo2 squares of one layer are above the larger Ln4Mo4 rings of the second (Figure ). This hampers the size of channels which are the broadest, 8.4 × 10.6 Å, in the [100] or [001] directions, not perpendicular to the plane of CN–-bridged layers (). The sliding of coordination layers is accompanied by different solvents in the interlayer space. Between layers of phases A and C, weakly bonded MeCN molecules have been found, while the supramolecular network in phase B is filled by water, stabilizing the interlayer space by strong hydrogen bonds with terminal cyanides. The interactions between layers in phases A and C are dominated by steric effects between DMF and Box, and only weak hydrogen bonds between O atoms of Box and methyl groups of DMF (phase A), or between terminal CN– and methyl groups of DMF (phase C), are observed ().

elements.content: The two-step sliding of coordination layers on going from phase A to B (step 1) and from phase B to phase C (step 2) depends not only on the nature of lanthanide­(III) but also on the change of solvent molecules. Thus, the mechanism involving the correlation between coordination spheres of LnIII and solvent–layer interactions is proposed. Lanthanides­(III) reveal a decreasing ionic radius which results in a steady decrease of Ln-N/O bonds (Figure ). This continuous process induces two-step abrupt changes in LnIII coordination spheres. Large CeIII, PrIII, and NdIII form two types of 9-coordinated [LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2]3+ units with parallel and perpendicular Box ligands, while SmIII initiates only one type of the complex with parallel Box ligands. Later, HoIII begins the series of 8-coordinated [LnIII(Box)­(DMF)3]3+ ions. These different coordination complexes are embedded into the identical cyanido-bridged layers affecting solvent–layer interactions. Due to the synthetic procedure, water molecules, coming only from hydrated LnIII salts, are primarily present in the interlayer space as they have stronger preference to LnIII centers than MeCN. This is connected with the preference of LnIII to oxygen coordination and with the stabilization of water by hydrogen bonds with terminal cyanides. We found that terminal cyanides are open for hydrogen bonds with solvent only for phase B, while for phase A and C, they are protected by hydrophobic hydrocarbon groups of DMF and box. As a result, the hydrogen bonding network is only formed for phase B, and we observe the related sliding of coordination layers. In phases A and C, where MeCN molecules are present, the steric effects dominate, and the microporous network with large channels is induced ().

elements.content: Except for compound 1, which reveals a green color, the crystals of all other compounds are yellow, which is related to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) of [MoV(CN)8]3– ions giving the strong absorption from the UV to blue-violet range (). In a special case of 1, the additional absorption around 620 nm can be assigned to CeIII–MoV metal-to-metal charge transfer (MMCT) as the CeIV and MoIV oxidation states are optically accessible. Taking advantage of strong absorption in the UV range, the luminescence properties of 1–12 were investigated by means of solid-state emission and excitation spectra at liquid nitrogen temperature, and the results are presented in Figures – and .
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

Except for compound 1, which reveals a green color, the crystals of all other compounds are yellow, which is related to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) of [MoV(CN)8]3- ions giving the strong absorption from the UV to blue-violet range (). In a special case of 1, the additional absorption around 620 nm can be assigned to CeIII-MoV metal-to-metal charge transfer (MMCT) as the CeIV and MoIV oxidation states are optically accessible. Taking advantage of strong absorption in the UV range, the luminescence properties of 1-12 were investigated by means of solid-state emission and excitation spectra at liquid nitrogen temperature, and the results are presented in Figures - and .

elements.content: Solid-state visible emission (right) and excitation (left) spectra at T = 77 K for 2 (a), 4 (b), 5 (c), and 9 (d) revealing ligand-to-metal energy transfer.
elements.clean_text: 3  Solid-state visible emission (right) and excitation (left) spectra at T = 77 K for 2 (a), 4 (b), 5 (c), and 9 (d) revealing ligand-to-metal energy transfer.

elements.content: Under irradiation of UV light, 2, 4, 5, and 9 exhibit the visible luminescence consisting of sharp peaks of f–f transitions (Figure ). 2 reveals red emission coming from three peaks at 625, 725, and 798 nm (Figure ). This is ascribed to phosphorescent f–f transitions from 1D2 state of PrIII to 3H J (J = 4, 5, 6) multiplets. SmIII-based 4 shows an orange color of emission due to the peak at 595 nm, accompanied by weaker bands at 560, 645, 708, and 790 nm. They are related to f–f 4G5/2 → 6H J (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2, 13/2) transitions. The red phosphorescence is observed also for 5 due to EuIII-centered 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) transitions giving the maxima at 580, 592, 615, 650, 695, 750, 810 nm, respectively. The different, yellowish green emission was detected for HoIII-based 9, which is caused by the dominant peak at 545 nm assigned to 5S2 + 5F4 → 5I8 fluorescence. Other transitions from 5S2 + 5F4 state to the 5I7 multiplet and from different 5F5 emissive state to the 5I8 ground state gave weaker peaks at 655 and 760 nm, respectively. In the excitation spectra of 2, 4, 5, and 9, a broad band centered around 350 is observed, suggesting the energy transfer process from Box coordinated to LnIII. This is supported by the absence of Box emission, which is expected to be ∼480 nm, and ∼640 nm, respectively. Besides the energy transfer mechanism, the direct intra-f excitation is possible in all compounds, as manifested by a series of sharp peaks in the excitation spectra. The other possible energy transfer pathway applying absorption to high energy ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) O → Eu band was detected for EuIII-based 5. Because of the sample preparation and the nature of solid state measurements, it is difficult to compare the luminescence intensity of 2, 4, 5, and 9 and the related efficiency of energy transfer. However, a rough comparison showed that EuIII in 5 reveals the emission ∼10 times stronger than observed for other LnIII in 2, 4, and 9 ().

elements.content: The visible emission was also found for 6 and 7 (Figure ). Due to the presence of GdIII, 6 cannot reveal f-centered emission, but it allows the observation of the broad red 3T1 → 1S0 phosphorescence of Box at 630 nm. Using 340 nm excitation light, a similar broad band ascribed to the 3T1 → 1S0 transition in Box was found for TbIII-containing 7. However, by using the higher energy excitation of 270 nm, the green emission represented by sharp peaks at 490, 545, 583, and 620 nm is observed. This can be assigned to characteristic f–f 5D4 → 7F J (J = 6, 5, 4, 3) transitions in TbIII. The different color of emission originates from the selective excitation of ligand and LnIII states as visible in the excitation spectra. For ligand emission, the expected broad band with the maxima at 360 and 440 nm is observed, when for TbIII emission, the strong peak is present at high energy of 260 nm, which is ascribed to the 4f8 → 4f75d1 transition. The direct TbIII excitation is more efficient than the phosphorescence of organic ligand, as found by a rough comparison of experimental intensities ().

elements.content: Using the irradiation of Box ligand with 340 nm line, 2, 3, 4, 9, and 12 emit the light in NIR range (Figure ). 2 shows dominant peak built of two components at 990 and 1020 nm, accompanied by weaker emission at 865 nm. They can be assigned to the f–f transitions from the 1D2 state to 3F J (J = 2, 3, 4) multiplets (Figure ). The NIR NdIII-centered fluorescence was found for 3, revealing sharp peaks at 900 and 1060 nm due to the 4F3/2 → 4I J (J = 9/2, 11/2) transitions. The emission in the similar region was found for SmIII in 4, where the maxima at 895, 940, and 1060 nm are detected. They are related to a complicated series of phosphorescent transitions from the 4G5/2 to 6H15/2 and various 6F J (J = 1/2, 3/2, 5/2, 7/2) states. The broader NIR emission was found for 9, exhibiting a complex band with two components at 980 and 1060 nm, explained by 5F5 → 5I7 and 5S2 + 5F4 → 5I6 fluorescent transitions, respectively. The emitted NIR light was observed also for 12, which reveals characteristic single peak at 995 nm of an YbIII-centered 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 origin. This compound is specific as YbIII has no other f–f states, and the excitation spectrum contains only the ligand-based bands at 350 and 455 nm, indicating the ligand-to-metal energy transfer mechanism in 12. The similarly located maxima of excitation were found for all NIR-emitting 2, 3, 4, and 9, but they exhibit also the direct-f excitation pathways by various wavelengths of visible light. In the rough comparison of the experimental intensities of NIR emission, the strongest peaks are those for NdIII of 3, which are four times stronger than for YbIII in 12 and more than 20 times stronger than peaks from other LnIII in 2, 4, and 9 ().

elements.content: The complementary studies of UV–vis-NIR absorption, emission, and excitation spectra allow us to construct the energy level diagram showing all luminescent effects, and accompanying processes of 1–12 (Figure ). The observed optical phenomena depends on the relative position between the triplet state of Box and the emissive state of LnIII. In 2, 3, 4, 5, 9, and 12, at least one emissive state of LnIII is within or below the range of Box 3T1 energy level, and thus, the energy transfer (ET) from Box to LnIII can be observed. For 2, PrIII has two possible emissive levels, but 3P0 is located too high for Box donors, and the emission from only 1D2 can be detected. In NIR-emitting 3 and 12, the NdIII and YbIII emissive states are situated below the 3T1 state, and ET is preferred. The emissive states of SmIII and EuIII are located in similar positions, both reasonably good for ET, which results in vis–NIR, or only vis emission, respectively. HoIII is a special case, possessing three too closely positioned emissive states, and all of them are within the range accessible for ET, so the complex vis–NIR luminescent characteristics are observed in 9. The potentially emissive states of GdIII, TbIII, DyIII, and TmIII, are situated too high for ET from Box. For GdIII-based 6 and TbIII-based 7, it results in ligand phosphorescence because the energy is not lost, as no other energy levels overlap with the 3T1 state of Box. It gave also the selective excitation of TbIII by using higher energy light. There is lack of even Box emission in 8 and 11, which is due to overlap between nonemissive states of DyIII and TmIII, with Box, inducing the nonradiative relaxation. The ET giving the emission could be also found for ErIII-containing 10; however, there is no signal, which is due to relaxation through the vibration modes, crucial for a small gap ErIII NIR emitters. The lack of emission in 1 is due to the overlap between 3T1 state of Box, and CeIII–MoV MMCT band of 1, and energy can be transferred from Box, but MMCT levels involving [MV(CN)8]3– are not emissive. There is no contribution from [MoV(CN)8]3– ions to the emission, which means that energy absorbed by their LMCT states are relaxed, not influencing on the equilibrium between LnIII and Box.

elements.content: Schematic energy level diagram explaining the mechanism of luminescent effects in 1–12. The straight lines correspond to absorption or emission, while the wavy lines present nonradiative relaxation. The ligand-to-metal energy transfer (ET) is presented as red arrows. The range of 3T1 ligand state was shown as the orange background, when the emissive states are presented as thick blue lines. The processes occurring under the irradiation by 340 nm wavelength were presented by black and red arrows, while the separate mechanism of direct excitation of TbIII using the light of 270 nm was shown using green arrows. Abbreviations: A – absorption, P – ligand phosphorescence, L – lanthanide luminescence, ET – energy transfer.

elements.content: Compounds 1–12 consist of two paramagnetic centers, MoV and LnIII, which can be magnetically coupled through cyanide bridges. The significant magnetic couplings were found for 1, 3, 4, 6–8, and their properties are presented below (Figures –), while the magnetism of 2, 5, 9–12, is dominated by standard single-ion properties of the respective lanthanide­(III) ion, so as they are discussed only in the (Figures S12–S14).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Compounds 1-12 consist of two paramagnetic centers, MoV and LnIII, which can be magnetically coupled through cyanide bridges. The significant magnetic couplings were found for 1, 3, 4, 6-8, and their properties are presented below (Figures -), while the magnetism of 2, 5, 9-12, is dominated by standard single-ion properties of the respective lanthanide(III) ion, so as they are discussed only in the  (Figures S12-S14).

elements.content: The room-temperature χM T is 1.04 cm3 mol–1 K for {CeIIIMoV} unit in agreement with the expected 1.18 cm3 mol–1 K for the uncoupled pair of CeIII (J = 5/2, g J = 6/7) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). On cooling, the χM T gradually decreases to 0.86 cm3 mol–1 K at 12 K, which is followed by abrupt increase to 0.99 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (Figure ). The steady decrease of the χM T is ascribed to the thermal depopulation of the Stark levels arising from the splitting of the 2F5/2 ground state of CeIII, whereas the further increase can be assigned to magnetic interactions within CeIII–NC–MoV linkages. The magnetization at T = 1.8 K increases with increasing magnetic field to 1.83 Nβ at 50 kOe, which is close to the range of 1.85–2.07 Nβ expected for combined contributions from CeIII and MoV, assuming a spin of S = 1/2 with g = 2 for MoV, and an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with g within the range of 1.71–2.15 for CeIII. The M at 50 kOe in 1 is higher than 1.61 Nβ found for one example of CeIII–MoV system for which positive J value of 1.4 cm–1 was proved. All these suggest a ferromagnetic type of CeIII–MoV coupling in 1. However, these interactions are weak, and FCM curves do not show abrupt increase of the signal, and ac signal is negligible (not shown), indicating the lack of magnetic ordering.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 1 

The room-temperature χM T is 1.04 cm3 mol-1 K for {CeIIIMoV} unit in agreement with the expected 1.18 cm3 mol-1 K for the uncoupled pair of CeIII (J = 5/2, g  J  = 6/7) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). On cooling, the χM T gradually decreases to 0.86 cm3 mol-1 K at 12 K, which is followed by abrupt increase to 0.99 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.8 K (Figure ). The steady decrease of the χM T is ascribed to the thermal depopulation of the Stark levels arising from the splitting of the 2F5/2 ground state of CeIII, whereas the further increase can be assigned to magnetic interactions within CeIII-NC-MoV linkages. The magnetization at T = 1.8 K increases with increasing magnetic field to 1.83 Nβ at 50 kOe, which is close to the range of 1.85-2.07 Nβ expected for combined contributions from CeIII and MoV, assuming a spin of S = 1/2 with g = 2 for MoV, and an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with g within the range of 1.71-2.15 for CeIII. The M at 50 kOe in 1 is higher than 1.61 Nβ found for one example of CeIII-MoV system for which positive J value of 1.4 cm-1 was proved. All these suggest a ferromagnetic type of CeIII-MoV coupling in 1. However, these interactions are weak, and FCM curves do not show abrupt increase of the signal, and ac signal is negligible (not shown), indicating the lack of magnetic ordering.

elements.content: At room temperature, the χM T reaches 1.67 cm3 mol–1 K for {NdIIIMoV}, which is lower than the value of 2.01 cm3 mol–1 K expected for the isolated pair of NdIII (J = 9/2, g J = 8/11) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). This is connected with thermal depopulation of NdIII Stark levels of the 4I9/2 ground state, which are not equally populated even at 300 K. This implies further decrease of χM T with decreasing temperature up to 1.07 cm3 mol–1 K at 9 K (Figure ). On the contrary, the abrupt increase of χM T below 9 K up to 1.43 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K has to be connected with the NdIII–MoV magnetic coupling. The magnetization at T = 1.8 K increases fast with increasing field giving the value of 2.13 Nβ, close to 2.25 Nβ calculated for a parallel alignment of MoV (S = 2, g = 1/2) and NdIII (S eff = 1/2, g eff = 2.5) magnetic moments. This together with the shape of χM T–T curve suggest the ferromagnetic character of NdIII–Mo V interactions, which agrees well with other reports on octacyanido-based compounds with NdIII. As validated by FCM curves showing only slow increase of the signal and ac measurements revealing no detectable signal (not shown), these interactions are too weak to induce magnetic ordering in 3.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 3 

At room temperature, the χM T reaches 1.67 cm3 mol-1 K for {NdIIIMoV}, which is lower than the value of 2.01 cm3 mol-1 K expected for the isolated pair of NdIII (J = 9/2, g  J  = 8/11) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). This is connected with thermal depopulation of NdIII Stark levels of the 4I9/2 ground state, which are not equally populated even at 300 K. This implies further decrease of χM T with decreasing temperature up to 1.07 cm3 mol-1 K at 9 K (Figure ). On the contrary, the abrupt increase of χM T below 9 K up to 1.43 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.8 K has to be connected with the NdIII-MoV magnetic coupling. The magnetization at T = 1.8 K increases fast with increasing field giving the value of 2.13 Nβ, close to 2.25 Nβ calculated for a parallel alignment of MoV (S = 2, g = 1/2) and NdIII (S eff = 1/2, g eff = 2.5) magnetic moments. This together with the shape of χM T-T curve suggest the ferromagnetic character of NdIII-Mo V interactions, which agrees well with other reports on octacyanido-based compounds with NdIII. As validated by FCM curves showing only slow increase of the signal and ac measurements revealing no detectable signal (not shown), these interactions are too weak to induce magnetic ordering in 3.

elements.content: Upon cooling, the χM T–T curve reveals almost linear decrease from the value of 0.82 cm3 mol–1 K for {SmIII MoV} unit at 300 K to 0.50 cm3 mol–1 K at 13 K (Figure ). The room-temperature χM T is higher than 0.46 cm3 mol–1 K expected for the isolated SmIII (J = 5/2, g J = 2/7) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). These characteristics are related to the special properties of SmIII for which not only Stark multiplets of the 6H5/2 ground state but also the low-lying 6H7/2 excited state can be populated at high temperature. At low temperatures, the abrupt increase of the χ M T product up to 0.95 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K is observed, and this can be ascribed to the SmIII–MoV interactions. They are relatively strong as the fast increase of magnetization in the M–H plot is observed. The value of M at 50 kOe is equal 1.22 Nβ, which is close to 1.28 Nβ expected for ferromagnetically coupled SmIII–MoV pair, assuming a spin of S = 1/2 with g = 2 for MoV and an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with the average g value of 0.57 for SmIII. At the same time, it is much higher than 0.72 Nβ calculated for the antiferromagnetic alignment of SmIII and MoV magnetic moments. This indicates a ferromagnetic character of coupling, similar to other SmIII–[MV(CN)8]3– systems. Moreover, FCM curves show the abrupt increase at low temperatures and further saturation, indicating a ferromagnetic ordering in 4. The critical temperature of T c = 2.0 K was estimated from the first derivative of FCM. The onset of magnetic ordering was confirmed by ac magnetism, however, the peak in χ″M T(T) plot was not clearly formed due to low T c ().

elements.content: The χM T product for {GdIII MoV} unit at 300 K reaches 8.26 cm3 mol–1 K, which agrees well with the isolated pair of GdIII (S = 7/2, g = 2) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). On cooling, the χM T is stable up to 100 K and later decreases to 7.81 cm3 mol–1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the abrupt increase to a maximum of 15.2 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K (Figure ). As GdIII has no first-order orbital contribution, the minimum on χM T–T plot indicates the GdIII–MoV antiferromagnetic coupling, which is later spread within the layers giving the large increase of χM T. This interpretation is supported by the M–H curve showing a fast increase to 6.2 Nβ at 50 kOe, close to 6.0 Nβ expected for the antiferromagnetically coupled GdIII–MoV pair. The maximum on χM T–T plot at low temperatures can suggest the transition to the ordered state. In fact, FCM curves show a fast increase of signal at low T, but the saturation is not reached, indicating that T c is on the border of the measurement range, which is also observed in ac magnetism ().
elements.clean_text:
Compound 6 

The χM T product for {GdIII MoV} unit at 300 K reaches 8.26 cm3 mol-1 K, which agrees well with the isolated pair of GdIII (S = 7/2, g = 2) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). On cooling, the χM T is stable up to 100 K and later decreases to 7.81 cm3 mol-1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the abrupt increase to a maximum of 15.2 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K (Figure ). As GdIII has no first-order orbital contribution, the minimum on χM T-T plot indicates the GdIII-MoV antiferromagnetic coupling, which is later spread within the layers giving the large  increase of χM T. This interpretation is supported by the M-H curve showing a fast increase to 6.2 Nβ at 50 kOe, close to 6.0 Nβ expected for the antiferromagnetically coupled GdIII-MoV pair. The maximum on χM T-T plot at low temperatures can suggest the transition to the ordered state. In fact, FCM curves show a fast increase of signal at low T, but the saturation is not reached, indicating that T c is on the border of the measurement range, which is also observed in ac magnetism ().

elements.content: Magnetic properties of 6: T dependence of χM T (H = 2 kOe) (a), FCM curves at various H (b), and H dependence of M at T = 1.8 K (b, the inset).

elements.content: At room temperature, the χM T value of {TbIII MoV} unit is 12.2 cm3 mol–1 K, which is the same as calculated for the uncoupled TbIII (J = 6, g J = 3/2)–MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2) pair. Upon cooling, χM T is stable to 100 K and later decreases to minimum of 11.2 cm3 mol–1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the increase to 19.5 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.5 K. At the lowest T, a further decrease of χM T is observed (Figure ). The minimum on the χM T–T curve is related to the thermal depopulation within the multiplets of 7F6 ground state of TbIII, whereas the increase below 11 K is due to TbIII–MoV magnetic coupling. Its character is suggested by the M–H plot showing the value of 5.6 Nβ at 50 kOe without saturation, which is close to 6.0 Nβ calculated for the ferromagnetically coupled TbIII (S eff = 1/2, g eff = 10)–MoV (S = 1/2, g = 1/2) unit. The very low T maximum on χM T(T) plot suggests the onset of magnetic ordering, which is easily visible in the FCM curves revealing an abrupt increase below 2.5 K, followed by saturation of M. The T c value of 2.2 K was determined by the first derivative of FCM. Compound 7 reveals narrow magnetic hysteresis with small coercive field of 12 Oe. The ac magnetic signals reveal also peaks typical for the magnetic phase transition. However, there is a weak frequency dependence, suggesting the contribution of spin glass behavior coexisting with ferromagnetism in 7. The similar dependences, but at lower temperatures, were observed also in 4 and 6, supporting the interpretation of a 3-D spin glass effect rather than the role of magnetic anisotropy ().

Compound 7 

At room temperature, the χM T value of {TbIII MoV} unit is 12.2 cm3 mol-1 K, which is the same as calculated for the uncoupled TbIII (J = 6, g  J  = 3/2)-MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2) pair. Upon cooling, χM T is stable to 100 K and later decreases to minimum of 11.2 cm3 mol-1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the increase to 19.5 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.5 K. At the lowest T, a further decrease of χM T is observed (Figure ). The minimum on the χM T-T curve is related to the thermal depopulation within the multiplets of 7F6 ground state of TbIII, whereas the increase below 11 K is due to TbIII-MoV magnetic coupling. Its character is suggested by the M-H plot showing the value of 5.6 Nβ at 50 kOe without saturation, which is close to 6.0 Nβ calculated for the ferromagnetically coupled TbIII (S eff = 1/2, g eff = 10)-MoV (S = 1/2, g = 1/2) unit. The very low T maximum on χM T(T) plot suggests the onset of magnetic ordering, which is easily visible in the FCM curves revealing an abrupt increase below 2.5 K, followed by saturation of M. The T c value of 2.2 K was determined by the first derivative of FCM. Compound 7 reveals narrow magnetic hysteresis with small coercive field of 12 Oe. The ac magnetic signals reveal also peaks typical for the magnetic phase transition. However, there is a weak frequency dependence, suggesting the contribution of spin glass behavior coexisting with ferromagnetism in 7. The similar dependences, but at lower temperatures, were observed also in 4 and 6, supporting the interpretation of a 3-D spin glass effect rather than the role of magnetic anisotropy ().

elements.content: The χM T for {DyIII MoV} unit reaches at 300 K the high value of 14.4 cm3 mol–1 K, close to the expected 14.5 cm3 mol–1 K for the isolated DyIII (J = 15/2, g J = 4/3)–MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2) pair. On cooling, the χM T–T plot is flat, while the gradual decrease is detected below 50 K, with the minimum of 12.7 cm3 mol–1 K at 9 K, which can be assigned to the depopulation of numerous multiplets within DyIII 6H15/2 ground state (Figure ). On further cooling, the rapid increase of signal is observed, and after the maximum at 2.2 K, the χM T finally decreases. These features relate to magnetic interactions within DyIII–NC–MoV. The M–H plot shows fast increase of magnetization to the value of 6.6 Nβ at 50 kOe without saturation. This high value can suggest the ferromagnetic type of DyIII–MoV coupling, consistent with the previous report, but the contribution from DyIII to the M strongly depends on detailed distribution of its Stark levels. Taking the average value of g Dy = 9.3 from simple inorganic salts, the prediction for ferromagnetic DyIII (S eff = 1/2)–MoV pair is 5.7 Nβ, while for antiferromagnetic case only 3.7 Nβ, suggesting the ferromagnetic interactions in 8. The maximum on χM T–T plot at very low T indicate the transition to the ordered state. FCM curves show fast increase of signal at low T, but the saturation is not reached up to 1.8 K, indicating that T c is at the limit of the measurement range, which is also observed in ac magnetism ().

elements.content: We have prepared and studied in detail a series of 4f–4d cyanido-bridged coordination polymers, {[LnIII(Box) n (DMF) m ]­[MoV(CN)8]}·x(solvent) (1–12) of a bifunctional magneto-luminescent character. We found the unusual two-step sliding of their coordination layers on going from {[LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2]­[MoV(CN)8]}·1.5MeCN phase A of light Ce–Nd, through intermediate {[LnIII(Box) 2(DMF)2]­[MoV(CN)8 ]}·H2O phase B (Sm–Dy) to {[LnIII(Box)­(DMF) 3]­[MoV(CN)8]·MeCN phase C of heavy lanthanides, (Ho–Yb).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have prepared and studied in detail a series of 4f-4d cyanido-bridged coordination polymers, {[LnIII(Box) n (DMF) m ][MoV(CN)8]}⋅x(solvent) (1-12) of a bifunctional magneto-luminescent character. We found the unusual two-step sliding of their coordination layers on going from {[LnIII(Box)2(DMF)2][MoV(CN)8]}⋅1.5MeCN phase A of light Ce-Nd, through intermediate {[LnIII(Box) 2(DMF)2][MoV(CN)8 ]}⋅H2O phase B (Sm-Dy) to {[LnIII(Box)(DMF) 3][MoV(CN)8]⋅MeCN phase C of heavy lanthanides, (Ho-Yb).

elements.content: Although light and heavy lanthanides show similar microporous structures with large channels due to the ideal “one above another” arrangement of the layers, intermediate lanthanides reveal shifted positions of layers giving much smaller pores. We explained this by the changes in the coordination sphere of LnIII influencing the solvent–layer interactions. Although the solvent-dependent sliding of coordination layers was previously shown, we have shown for the first time how such lanthanides exert control over the preference of solvent and the related sliding of layers.
elements.clean_text: Although light and heavy lanthanides show similar microporous structures with large channels due to the ideal "one above another" arrangement of the layers, intermediate lanthanides reveal shifted positions of layers giving much smaller pores. We explained this by the changes in the coordination sphere of LnIII influencing the solvent-layer interactions. Although the solvent-dependent sliding of coordination layers was previously shown, we have shown for the first time how such lanthanides exert control over the preference of solvent and the related sliding of layers.

elements.content: We have also proved that [M­(CN)8]-based coordination polymers with embedded 4f metal ions coordinating the additional emissive organic molecule can be convenient molecular platforms to induce a diversity of luminescent effects. We have shown the ligand-to-metal energy transfer resulting in the multicolored HoIII green, SmIII orange, and PrIII or EuIII red f-centered emission or in the near-infrared luminescence of five different characteristics found for PrIII, NdIII, SmIII, HoIII, and YbIII-based materials. We presented ligand emission in GdIII containers and selective excitation of ligand or metal excited states giving red to green emission in TbIII–MoV. Thus, we expanded a set of cyanido-bridged bimetallic luminophors, showing for the first time Pr III , Sm III , and Ho III emission in the cyanido-bridged assemblies.
elements.clean_text: We have also proved that [M(CN)8]-based coordination polymers with embedded 4f metal ions coordinating the additional emissive organic molecule can be convenient molecular platforms to induce a diversity of luminescent effects. We have shown the ligand-to-metal energy transfer resulting in the multicolored HoIII green, SmIII orange, and PrIII or EuIII red f-centered emission or in the near-infrared luminescence of five different characteristics found for PrIII, NdIII, SmIII, HoIII, and YbIII-based materials. We presented ligand emission in GdIII containers and selective excitation of ligand or metal excited states giving red to green emission in TbIII-MoV. Thus, we expanded a set of cyanido-bridged bimetallic luminophors, showing for the first time Pr  III , Sm  III , and Ho  III  emission in the cyanido-bridged assemblies.

elements.content: Taking advantage of paramagnetism in both types of 4f and 4d metal ions connected by cyanide bridges in 1–12, we showed the magnetic coupling, and magnetic ordering observed in the SmIII–MoV (T c = 2.0 K), TbIII–MoV (T c = 2.2 K), GdIII–MoV (T c ∼ 1.8 K), and DyIII–MoV (T c ∼ 1.8 K) analogues. Thus, we can consider the obtained coordination polymers as a rare family of magneto-luminescent molecular materials. In this aspect, the organic ligand controls the topology of 1–12, giving the possibility to observe magnetic coupling within the cyanido-bridged network. The presented discussion on mechanisms govern the structural dynamics, optical and magnetic properties which can be used in the improvement of magneto-luminescent bifunctionality of 1–12, and similar materials. Modification of synthetic conditions should give the control over the sliding of coordination of layers and the resulting microporous structures which can be explored as a potential source of magneto-luminescent sensing. The introduction of modified ligand can amend the optical properties and the magnetism through changes in a cyanido-bridged connectivity. The insertion of chiral species is another interesting route, and enantiopure bis­(oxazoline) ligands can be achievable. These enhancements will expand the multifunctional potential of the materials. These perspectives are worth investigating in the near future.

Thus, we can consider the obtained coordination polymers as a rare family of magneto-luminescent molecular materials. In this aspect, the organic ligand controls the topology of 1-12, giving the possibility to observe magnetic coupling within the cyanido-bridged network. The presented discussion on mechanisms govern the structural dynamics, optical and magnetic properties which can be used in the improvement of magneto-luminescent bifunctionality of 1-12, and similar materials. cln_elements.content:
The title compound was produced as yellowish green needle crystals. The formula was found from the X-ray diffraction experiment. After filtration, washing by Et2O, and air-drying, 1 exchanges MeCN solvent into H2O to give air-stable composition, [CeIII(Box)2(DMF)2]2[MoV(CN)8]2·3H2O (formula taken from CHN analysis). Yield: 6.2 mg, 34%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2178w, 2172w, 2163m, 2152m, 2130w. Anal. Calcd for Ce1Mo1C26H36N14O9 (M w = 924.7 g·mol–1): C, 33.77%; H, 3.92%; N, 21.21%. Found: C, 33.64%; H, 4.01%; N, 21.10%. It is important to note that among the overwhelming amount of needle crystals, a few block crystals were observed. They are the second phase, [CeIII(Box)2(DMF)2]2[MoV(CN)8]2·H2O, analogous to that found for 2–8. However, the quality of these crystals were poor, and attempts to characterize them by X-ray experiment were unsuccessful.

[Pr<sup>III</sup>(Box)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·1.5MeCN (<bold>2a</bold>)

The title compound was produced as yellow needle crystals. The formula was taken from the results of X-ray diffraction experiment. Filtration, washing by Et2O, and air-drying result in the exchange of solvent molecules of MeCN by H2O, which gives the air-stable composition of 2a, [PrIII(Box)2(DMF)2]2[MoV(CN)8]2·3H2O. Yield: 5.2 mg, 28%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2180w, 2173w, 2164m, 2152m, 2130w. Anal. Calcd for Pr1Mo1C26H36N14O9 (M w = 925.5 g·mol–1): C, 33.74%; H, 3.92%; N, 21.19%. Found: C, 33.45%; H, 4.11%; N, 20.93%.

[Nd<sup>III</sup>(Box)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·1.5MeCN (<bold>3a</bold>)

The title compound was produced as yellow needle crystals. The formula was found from the X-ray diffraction structural analysis. After filtration, washing by Et2O, and air-drying, 3a exchanges solvent molecules of MeCN into H2O to give air-stable composition, [NdIII(Box)2 (DMF)2]2[MoV(CN)8]2·3H2O. Yield: 6.1 mg, 33%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2181w, 2173w, 2165m, 2153m, 2127w. Anal. Calcd for Nd1Mo1C26H36N14O9 (M w = 928.8 g·mol–1): C, 33.62%; H, 3.91%; N, 21.11%. Found: C, 33.76%; H, 3.82%; N, 21.27%.

[Sm<sup>III</sup>(Box)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

The title compound was produced as air-stable yellow block crystals. The formula found from the X-ray diffraction experiment is in a good agreement with the results of CHN analysis. Yield: 7.0 mg, 39%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2180m, 2170sh, 2167m, 2152m, 2135w. Anal. Calcd for Sm1Mo1C26H32N14O7 (M w = 898.9 g·mol–1): C, 34.74%; H, 3.59%; N, 21.81%. Found: C, 34.47%; H, 3.92%; N, 21.57%.

[Eu<sup>III</sup>(Box)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

The title compound was produced as air-stable yellow block crystals. The formula taken from the X-ray diffraction experiment corresponds well with the results of CHN analysis. Yield: 6.5 mg, 36%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2179m, 2170sh, 2165m, 2152w, 2135w. Anal. Calcd for Eu1Mo1C26H32N14O7 (M w = 900.5 g·mol–1): C, 34.58%; H, 3.58%; N, 21.78%. Found: C, 34.24%; H, 3.71%; N, 21.64%.

[Gd<sup>III</sup>(Box)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>6</bold>)

The title compound was produced as air-stable yellow block crystals. The formula found from the X-ray diffraction experiment agrees well with the results of CHN analysis. Yield: 7.5 mg, 41%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2180m, 2171sh, 2167m, 2152w, 2136w. Anal. Calcd for Gd1Mo1C26H32N14O7 (M w = 905.8 g·mol–1): C, 34.47%; H, 3.56%; N, 21.65%. Found: C, 34.14%; H, 3.80%; N, 21.40%.

[Tb<sup>III</sup>(Box)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>7</bold>)

The title compound was produced as air-stable yellow block crystals. The formula found from the X-ray diffraction structural analysis agrees well with the results of CHN analysis. Yield: 6.2 mg, 34%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2181m, 2172sh, 2168m, 2152w, 2136vw. Anal. Calcd for Tb1Mo1C26H32N14O7 (M w = 907.5 g·mol–1): C, 34.41%; H, 3.55%; N, 21.61%. Found: C, 34.14%; H, 3.75%; N, 21.42%.

[Dy<sup>III</sup>(Box)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>8</bold>)

The title compound was produced as air-stable yellow block crystals. The formula found from the X-ray diffraction structural analysis agrees well with the results of CHN analysis. Yield: 5.7 mg, 31%. IR (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2179m, 2169m, 2152w, 2135w. Anal. Calcd for Dy1Mo1C26 H32N14O7 (M w = 911.7 g·mol–1): C, 34.28%; H, 3.54%; N, 21.52%. Found: C, 33.90%; H, 3.70%; N, 21.29%.

[Ho<sup>III</sup>(Box)­(DMF)<sub>3</sub>]­[Mo<sup>V</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·MeCN (<bold>9</bold>)

cln_elements.content:
The room-temperature χM T is 1.04 cm3 mol–1 K for {CeIIIMoV} unit in agreement with the expected 1.18 cm3 mol–1 K for the uncoupled pair of CeIII (J = 5/2, g J = 6/7) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). On cooling, the χM T gradually decreases to 0.86 cm3 mol–1 K at 12 K, which is followed by abrupt increase to 0.99 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (Figure ). The steady decrease of the χM T is ascribed to the thermal depopulation of the Stark levels arising from the splitting of the 2F5/2 ground state of CeIII, whereas the further increase can be assigned to magnetic interactions within CeIII–NC–MoV linkages. The magnetization at T = 1.8 K increases with increasing magnetic field to 1.83 Nβ at 50 kOe, which is close to the range of 1.85–2.07 Nβ expected for combined contributions from CeIII and MoV, assuming a spin of S = 1/2 with g = 2 for MoV, and an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with g within the range of 1.71–2.15 for CeIII. The M at 50 kOe in 1 is higher than 1.61 Nβ found for one example of CeIII–MoV system for which positive J value of 1.4 cm–1 was proved. All these suggest a ferromagnetic type of CeIII–MoV coupling in 1. However, these interactions are weak, and FCM curves do not show abrupt increase of the signal, and ac signal is negligible (not shown), indicating the lack of magnetic ordering.

Compound <bold>4</bold>

Upon cooling, the χM T–T curve reveals almost linear decrease from the value of 0.82 cm3 mol–1 K for {SmIII MoV} unit at 300 K to 0.50 cm3 mol–1 K at 13 K (Figure ). The room-temperature χM T is higher than 0.46 cm3 mol–1 K expected for the isolated SmIII (J = 5/2, g J = 2/7) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). These characteristics are related to the special properties of SmIII for which not only Stark multiplets of the 6H5/2 ground state but also the low-lying 6H7/2 excited state can be populated at high temperature. At low temperatures, the abrupt increase of the χ M T product up to 0.95 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K is observed, and this can be ascribed to the SmIII–MoV interactions. They are relatively strong as the fast increase of magnetization in the M–H plot is observed. The value of M at 50 kOe is equal 1.22 Nβ, which is close to 1.28 Nβ expected for ferromagnetically coupled SmIII–MoV pair, assuming a spin of S = 1/2 with g = 2 for MoV and an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with the average g value of 0.57 for SmIII. At the same time, it is much higher than 0.72 Nβ calculated for the antiferromagnetic alignment of SmIII and MoV magnetic moments. This indicates a ferromagnetic character of coupling, similar to other SmIII–[MV(CN)8]3– systems. Moreover, FCM curves show the abrupt increase at low temperatures and further saturation, indicating a ferromagnetic ordering in 4. The critical temperature of T c = 2.0 K was estimated from the first derivative of FCM. The onset of magnetic ordering was confirmed by ac magnetism, however, the peak in χ″M T(T) plot was not clearly formed due to low T c ().

Compound <bold>6</bold>

The χM T product for {GdIII MoV} unit at 300 K reaches 8.26 cm3 mol–1 K, which agrees well with the isolated pair of GdIII (S = 7/2, g = 2) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). On cooling, the χM T is stable up to 100 K and later decreases to 7.81 cm3 mol–1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the abrupt increase to a maximum of 15.2 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K (Figure ). As GdIII has no first-order orbital contribution, the minimum on χM T–T plot indicates the GdIII–MoV antiferromagnetic coupling, which is later spread within the layers giving the large increase of χM T. This interpretation is supported by the M–H curve showing a fast increase to 6.2 Nβ at 50 kOe, close to 6.0 Nβ expected for the antiferromagnetically coupled GdIII–MoV pair. The maximum on χM T–T plot at low temperatures can suggest the transition to the ordered state. In fact, FCM curves show a fast increase of signal at low T, but the saturation is not reached, indicating that T c is on the border of the measurement range, which is also observed in ac magnetism ().

Compound <bold>7</bold>

At room temperature, the χM T value of {TbIII MoV} unit is 12.2 cm3 mol–1 K, which is the same as calculated for the uncoupled TbIII (J = 6, g J = 3/2)–MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2) pair. Upon cooling, χM T is stable to 100 K and later decreases to minimum of 11.2 cm3 mol–1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the increase to 19.5 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.5 K. At the lowest T, a further decrease of χM T is observed (Figure ). The minimum on the χM T–T curve is related to the thermal depopulation within the multiplets of 7F6 ground state of TbIII, whereas the increase below 11 K is due to TbIII–MoV magnetic coupling. Its character is suggested by the M–H plot showing the value of 5.6 Nβ at 50 kOe without saturation, which is close to 6.0 Nβ calculated for the ferromagnetically coupled TbIII (S eff = 1/2, g eff = 10)–MoV (S = 1/2, g = 1/2) unit. The very low T maximum on χM T(T) plot suggests the onset of magnetic ordering, which is easily visible in the FCM curves revealing an abrupt increase below 2.5 K, followed by saturation of M. The T c value of 2.2 K was determined by the first derivative of FCM. Compound 7 reveals narrow magnetic hysteresis with small coercive field of 12 Oe. The ac magnetic signals reveal also peaks typical for the magnetic phase transition. However, there is a weak frequency dependence, suggesting the contribution of spin glass behavior coexisting with ferromagnetism in 7. The similar dependences, but at lower temperatures, were observed also in 4 and 6, supporting the interpretation of a 3-D spin glass effect rather than the role of magnetic anisotropy ().

Compound <bold>8</bold>

The χM T for {DyIII MoV} unit reaches at 300 K the high value of 14.4 cm3 mol–1 K, close to the expected 14.5 cm3 mol–1 K for the isolated DyIII (J = 15/2, g J = 4/3)–MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2) pair. On cooling, the χM T–T plot is flat, while the gradual decrease is detected below 50 K, with the minimum of 12.7 cm3 mol–1 K at 9 K, which can be assigned to the depopulation of numerous multiplets within DyIII 6H15/2 ground state (Figure ). On further cooling, the rapid increase of signal is observed, and after the maximum at 2.2 K, the χM T finally decreases. These features relate to magnetic interactions within DyIII–NC–MoV. The M–H plot shows fast increase of magnetization to the value of 6.6 Nβ at 50 kOe without saturation. This high value can suggest the ferromagnetic type of DyIII–MoV coupling, consistent with the previous report, but the contribution from DyIII to the M strongly depends on detailed distribution of its Stark levels. Taking the average value of g Dy = 9.3 from simple inorganic salts, the prediction for ferromagnetic DyIII (S eff = 1/2)–MoV pair is 5.7 Nβ, while for antiferromagnetic case only 3.7 Nβ, suggesting the ferromagnetic interactions in 8. The maximum on χM T–T plot at very low T indicate the transition to the ordered state. FCM curves show fast increase of signal at low T, but the saturation is not reached up to 1.8 K, indicating that T c is at the limit of the measurement range, which is also observed in ac magnetism ().
