These characteristics are related to the special properties of SmIII for which not only Stark multiplets of the 6H5/2 ground state but also the low-lying 6H7/2 excited state can be populated at high temperature. At low temperatures, the abrupt increase of the χ M T product up to 0.95 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.8 K is observed, and this can be ascribed to the SmIII-MoV interactions. They are relatively strong as the fast increase of magnetization in the M-H plot is observed. The value of M at 50 kOe is equal 1.22 Nβ, which is close to 1.28 Nβ expected for ferromagnetically coupled SmIII-MoV pair, assuming a spin of S = 1/2 with g = 2 for MoV and an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with the average g value of 0.57 for SmIII. At the same time, it is much higher than 0.72 Nβ calculated for the antiferromagnetic alignment of SmIII and MoV magnetic moments. This indicates a ferromagnetic character of coupling, similar to other SmIII-[MV(CN)8]3- systems. Moreover, FCM curves show the abrupt increase at low temperatures and further saturation, indicating a ferromagnetic ordering in 4. The critical temperature of T c = 2.0 K was estimated from the first derivative of FCM. The onset of magnetic ordering was confirmed by ac magnetism, however, the peak in χ"M T(T) plot was not clearly formed due to low T c ().

Compound 6 

The χM T product for {GdIII MoV} unit at 300 K reaches 8.26 cm3 mol-1 K, which agrees well with the isolated pair of GdIII (S = 7/2, g = 2) and MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2). On cooling, the χM T is stable up to 100 K and later decreases to 7.81 cm3 mol-1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the abrupt increase to a maximum of 15.2 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K (Figure ). As GdIII has no first-order orbital contribution, the minimum on χM T-T plot indicates the GdIII-MoV antiferromagnetic coupling, which is later spread within the layers giving the large  increase of χM T. This interpretation is supported by the M-H curve showing a fast increase to 6.2 Nβ at 50 kOe, close to 6.0 Nβ expected for the antiferromagnetically coupled GdIII-MoV pair. The maximum on χM T-T plot at low temperatures can suggest the transition to the ordered state. In fact, FCM curves show a fast increase of signal at low T, but the saturation is not reached, indicating that T c is on the border of the measurement range, which is also observed in ac magnetism ().

Compound 7 

At room temperature, the χM T value of {TbIII MoV} unit is 12.2 cm3 mol-1 K, which is the same as calculated for the uncoupled TbIII (J = 6, g  J  = 3/2)-MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2) pair. Upon cooling, χM T is stable to 100 K and later decreases to minimum of 11.2 cm3 mol-1 K at 11 K, which is followed by the increase to 19.5 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.5 K. At the lowest T, a further decrease of χM T is observed (Figure ). The minimum on the χM T-T curve is related to the thermal depopulation within the multiplets of 7F6 ground state of TbIII, whereas the increase below 11 K is due to TbIII-MoV magnetic coupling. Its character is suggested by the M-H plot showing the value of 5.6 Nβ at 50 kOe without saturation, which is close to 6.0 Nβ calculated for the ferromagnetically coupled TbIII (S eff = 1/2, g eff = 10)-MoV (S = 1/2, g = 1/2) unit. The very low T maximum on χM T(T) plot suggests the onset of magnetic ordering, which is easily visible in the FCM curves revealing an abrupt increase below 2.5 K, followed by saturation of M. The T c value of 2.2 K was determined by the first derivative of FCM. Compound 7 reveals narrow magnetic hysteresis with small coercive field of 12 Oe. The ac magnetic signals reveal also peaks typical for the magnetic phase transition. However, there is a weak frequency dependence, suggesting the contribution of spin glass behavior coexisting with ferromagnetism in 7. The similar dependences, but at lower temperatures, were observed also in 4 and 6, supporting the interpretation of a 3-D spin glass effect rather than the role of magnetic anisotropy ().

Compound 8 

The χM T for {DyIII MoV} unit reaches at 300 K the high value of 14.4 cm3 mol-1 K, close to the expected 14.5 cm3 mol-1 K for the isolated DyIII (J = 15/2, g  J  = 4/3)-MoV (S = 1/2, g = 2) pair. On cooling, the χM T-T plot is flat, while the gradual decrease is detected below 50 K, with the minimum of 12.7 cm3 mol-1 K at 9 K, which can be assigned to the depopulation of numerous multiplets within DyIII 6H15/2 ground state (Figure ). On further cooling, the rapid increase of signal is observed, and after the maximum at 2.2 K, the χM T finally decreases. These features relate to magnetic interactions within DyIII-NC-MoV. The M-H plot shows fast increase of magnetization to the value of 6.6 Nβ at 50 kOe without saturation. This high value can suggest the ferromagnetic type of DyIII-MoV coupling, consistent with the previous report, but the contribution from DyIII to the M strongly depends on detailed distribution of its Stark levels. Taking the average value of g Dy = 9.3 from simple inorganic salts, the prediction for ferromagnetic DyIII (S eff = 1/2)-MoV pair is 5.7 Nβ, while for antiferromagnetic case only 3.7 Nβ, suggesting the ferromagnetic interactions in 8. The maximum on χM T-T plot at very low T indicate the transition to the ordered state. FCM curves show fast increase of signal at low T, but the saturation is not reached up to 1.8 K, indicating that T c is at the limit of the measurement range, which is also observed in ac magnetism ().
